elements.content: The first/second examples of partially oxidized 1-D platinum chain compounds consisting of cationic dimer units have been obtained from electro-oxidation of an aqueous solution containing cis-[Pt(NH3)2(OH2)2]2+ and acetate/propionate. The analytical and crystallographic studies reveal the mixed-valency of Pt(2.2+)∞. The XPS confirms the presence of both Pt(II) and Pt(III). The solid-state physical measurements reveal that they are diamagnetic semiconductors and display a fairly broad, low-energy absorption band in the range of 500−3200 nm.
elements.clean_text: The first/second examples of partially oxidized 1-D platinum chain compounds consisting of cationic dimer units have been obtained from electro-oxidation of an aqueous solution containing cis-[Pt(NH3)2(OH2)2]2+ and acetate/propionate. The analytical and crystallographic studies reveal the mixed-valency of Pt(2.2+)∞. The XPS confirms the presence of both Pt(II) and Pt(III). The solid-state physical measurements reveal that they are diamagnetic semiconductors and display a fairly broad, low-energy absorption band in the range of 500-3200 nm.

elements.content: Crystals of 1-D metal chain complexes have attracted considerable attention due to their highly anisotropic physical properties. One of the promising metals to attain such systems is Pt, since square-planar Pt(II) complexes often stack in the crystal to give 1-D Pt(II)∞ chains. The special affinity between the Pt(II) centers, that is, the weak metal−metal bonding character is now believed to be due to the mixing of filled 5d z 2 and vacant 6p orbitals. Moreover, metal−metal bonds are efficiently reinforced by partial oxidation at the metal centers to afford highly delocalized mixed-valence systems exhibiting metallic conductivity (formally [Pt(II) x Pt(III) y ]∞). Nevertheless, mononuclear anions, such as [Pt(CN)4]2- and [Pt(C2O4)2]2-, are the only examples affording such systems (e.g., Pt(2.3+)∞). Thus, the ability of chemists to rationally synthesize such systems is quite limited. Therefore, it must be questioned if it is possible to obtain such systems by use of other types of repeating units.
elements.clean_text: Crystals of 1-D metal chain complexes have attracted considerable attention due to their highly anisotropic physical properties. One of the promising metals to attain such systems is Pt, since square-planar Pt(II) complexes often stack in the crystal to give 1-D Pt(II)∞ chains. The special affinity between the Pt(II) centers, that is, the weak metal-metal bonding character is now believed to be due to the mixing of filled 5d z   2  and vacant 6p orbitals. Moreover, metal-metal bonds are efficiently reinforced by partial oxidation at the metal centers to afford highly delocalized mixed-valence systems exhibiting metallic conductivity (formally [Pt(II) x Pt(III) y ]∞). Nevertheless, mononuclear anions, such as [Pt(CN)4]2- and [Pt(C2O4)2]2-, are the only examples affording such systems (e.g., Pt(2.3+)∞). Thus, the ability of chemists to rationally synthesize such systems is quite limited. Therefore, it must be questioned if it is possible to obtain such systems by use of other types of repeating units.

elements.content: In the above context, we previously reported on some carboxylate-bridged cis-diammineplatinum dimer cations [Pt(II)2(NH3)4(μ-carboxylato)2]2+ (carboxylate = acetate, 1; glycolate, 2) which do afford 1-D [Pt(II)2]∞ chains in the crystal (see below; see also Table ). We also pointed out that the dimer−dimer associations are effectively stabilized by the quadruple hydrogen bonds formed between the ammines and the oxygen atoms of carboxylates. However, the preparation of partially oxidized chains extended with more effective Pt−Pt bonds had been unsuccessful. Two years ago, we found that controlled-current electrolysis is an appropriate method to obtain such compounds. Here we communicate the syntheses, crystal structures, and electronic properties of acetate- and propionate-bridged 1-D [Pt(2.2+)2]∞ chain complexes, as the first report of 1-D mixed-valence chains consisting of dinuclear cations. It must be emphasized that this is an extended work for the so-called “platinum blues” ([Pt(2.25+)2(NH3)4(μ-amidato)2] n 5 n +, n = 2 and 4), that is, the tetraplatinum and octaplatinum chain complexes made up of amidate-bridged dinuclear cations.
elements.clean_text: In the above context, we previously reported on some carboxylate-bridged cis-diammineplatinum dimer cations [Pt(II)2(NH3)4(μ-carboxylato)2]2+ (carboxylate = acetate, 1; glycolate, 2) which do afford 1-D [Pt(II)2]∞ chains in the crystal (see below; see also Table ). We also pointed out that the dimer-dimer associations are effectively stabilized by the quadruple hydrogen bonds formed between the ammines and the oxygen atoms of carboxylates. However, the preparation of partially oxidized chains extended with more effective Pt-Pt bonds had been unsuccessful. Two years ago, we found that controlled-current electrolysis is an appropriate method to obtain such compounds. Here we communicate the syntheses, crystal structures, and electronic properties of acetate- and propionate-bridged 1-D [Pt(2.2+)2]∞ chain complexes, as the first report of 1-D mixed-valence chains consisting of dinuclear cations. It must be emphasized that this is an extended work for the so-called "platinum blues" ([Pt(2.25+)2(NH3)4(μ-amidato)2] n  5  n  +, n = 2 and 4), that is, the tetraplatinum and octaplatinum chain complexes made up of amidate-bridged dinuclear cations.

elements.content:
<fig id="ja0275461f1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ja0275461f1.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The title compounds [Pt(2.2+)2(NH3)4(μ-acetato)2](NO3)2.4·2H2O (3) and [Pt(2.2+)2(NH3)4(μ-propionato)2](NO3)2(ClO4)0.4·2H2O (4) were prepared as follows. An aqueous solution of cis-[Pt(NH3)2(OH2)2]X2 (X = ClO4 -) and sodium acetate (or propionate) was separated into two phases with an agar NaNO3 bridge, and was electrolyzed (2 μA, 30 °C, in air) for 3 weeks to give dark brown needles of 3 (or 4) (Figure ). At the final stage of electrolysis, the color of the anodic solution turned dark brown, while that of the cathodic turned dark blue. To clarify the optimum synthetic conditions, experiments were repeatedly performed by changing (i) the concentrations of the starting materials, (ii) the counterion X, (iii) the concentration/kind of salt in the agar separator (NaClO4 and Na2SO4 were also tested), (iv) the temperature, and (v) the current applied. The most important finding is that the NO3 - involved in 3 and 4 as the counterion must be added only to the salt bridge, for a much smaller amount of crystals having a lower quality deposited when X = NO3 -. Therefore, slow diffusion of NO3 - from the salt bridge into the anodic solution plays a key role in the growth of quality crystals in a higher yield (20−30%).
elements.clean_text: The title compounds [Pt(2.2+)2(NH3)4(μ-acetato)2](NO3)2.4⋅2H2O (3) and [Pt(2.2+)2(NH3)4(μ-propionato)2](NO3)2(ClO4)0.4⋅2H2O (4) were prepared as follows. An aqueous solution of cis-[Pt(NH3)2(OH2)2]X2 (X = ClO4 -) and sodium acetate (or propionate) was separated into two phases with an agar NaNO3 bridge, and was electrolyzed (2 μA, 30 °C, in air) for 3 weeks to give dark brown needles of 3 (or 4) (Figure ). At the final stage of electrolysis, the color of the anodic solution turned dark brown, while that of the cathodic turned dark blue. To clarify the optimum synthetic conditions, experiments were repeatedly performed by changing (i) the concentrations of the starting materials, (ii) the counterion X, (iii) the concentration/kind of salt in the agar separator (NaClO4 and Na2SO4 were also tested), (iv) the temperature, and (v) the current applied. The most important finding is that the NO3 - involved in 3 and 4 as the counterion must be added only to the salt bridge, for a much smaller amount of crystals having a lower quality deposited when X = NO3 -. Therefore, slow diffusion of NO3 - from the salt bridge into the anodic solution plays a key role in the growth of quality crystals in a higher yield (20-30%).

elements.content: Dark brown needles of3 grown on the surface of the anode.
elements.clean_text: 1  Dark brown needles of3 grown on the surface of the anode.

elements.content: Compounds 3 and 4 are judged to be pure and are stable in air at room temperature. Due to the severe disorder phenomena together with the slight batch dependence observed during the structure refinement studies, there still remain uncertainties about the formulations of 3 and 4. However, the reported formulas do explain the analytical data obtained thus far as well as the results of our disorder analysis. The crystal of 3 involves two independent dimer units. Each dimer forms an infinite chain of its own. One grows a chain with inversion symmetry (3-i), the other, with glidal symmetry (3-g) (Figure ). Nevertheless, the structural features well resemble each other (Table ). On the other hand, a very similar Pt(2.2+)∞ chain is found in the crystal of 4 (Table ; Figure ), suggesting that the average Pt oxidation levels of 3 and 4 are roughly the same. Both the bridged and nonbridged Pt−Pt distances in 3 and 4 are much shorter than those in the [Pt(II)2]∞ chains in 1 and 2 (see Table ). Moreover, the linearity of chain is significantly improved in 3 and 4. Thus, the partial oxidation at the Pt centers is effectively promoted in 3 and 4. In addition, all the Pt−Pt distances observed for 1−4 well fit the correlation between the Pt−Pt distance and the average Pt oxidation state which has been reported thus far for the amidate-bridged platinum-blue family (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: Compounds 3  and 4  are judged to be pure and are stable in air at room temperature. Due to the severe disorder phenomena together with the slight batch dependence observed during the structure refinement studies, there still remain uncertainties about the formulations of     3 and 4. However, the reported formulas do explain the analytical data obtained thus far as well as the results of our disorder analysis. The crystal of 3  involves two independent dimer units. Each dimer forms an infinite chain of its own. One grows a chain with inversion symmetry (3-i), the other, with glidal symmetry (3-g) (Figure ). Nevertheless, the structural features well resemble each other (Table ). On the other hand, a very similar Pt(2.2+)∞ chain is found in the crystal of 4  (Table ; Figure ), suggesting that the average Pt oxidation levels of 3 and 4 are roughly the same. Both the bridged and nonbridged Pt-Pt distances in 3 and 4 are much shorter than those in the [Pt(II)2]∞ chains in 1 and 2 (see Table ). Moreover, the linearity of chain is significantly improved in 3 and 4. Thus, the partial oxidation at the Pt centers is effectively promoted in 3 and 4. In addition, all the Pt-Pt distances observed for 1-4 well fit the correlation between the Pt-Pt distance and the average Pt oxidation state which has been reported thus far for the amidate-bridged platinum-blue family (Figure S4).

a  Dihedral cant between the bridged Pt coordination planes. b  Twist angle about the Pt−Pt vector of the bridged Pt coordination planes. c  O(carboxylate) ···N(ammine) distances. d  Values reported in ref . e  Values for one of two disordered structures. f  Values for the other disordered structure.

The XPS spectrum of 4 at the Pt 4f region consists of two sets of doublets (4f7/2 and 4f5/2), confirming the presence of both Pt(II) and Pt(III) (Figure S5). ESR (113−300 K) measurements reveal the diamagnetic characters of 3 and 4, indicating that the unpaired electrons derived from Pt(III)s are predominantly coupled. The solid-state absorption spectra of 3 and 4 (Nujol mull method) display a fairly broad band ranging from 500 to 3200 nm (Figure S6). The room-temperature single-crystal electrical conductivities (4 probe, d.c.) of 3 (0.01 S/cm) and 4 (0.001 S/cm) reveal semiconducting characters of the materials.
elements.clean_text: The XPS spectrum of 4 at the Pt 4f region consists of two sets of doublets (4f7/2 and 4f5/2), confirming the presence of both Pt(II)  and Pt(III) (Figure S5). ESR (113-300 K) measurements reveal the diamagnetic characters of 3 and 4, indicating that the unpaired electrons derived from Pt(III)s are predominantly coupled. The solid-state absorption spectra of 3 and 4 (Nujol mull method) display a fairly broad band ranging from 500 to 3200 nm (Figure S6). The room-temperature single-crystal electrical conductivities (4 probe, d.c.) of 3 (0.01 S/cm) and 4 (0.001 S/cm) reveal semiconducting characters of the materials.

elements.content: Combined results obtained thus far deny a simpler description of Pt(2.25+)∞ (formally [Pt(II)3Pt(III)]∞) for the present systems, and rather support the reported mixed-valency of Pt(2.2+)∞ (formally [Pt(II)4Pt(III)]∞), which has an implication of a one-dimensional superstructure along the c axis (e.g., 5/2 c). Work in progress aims to more fully understand these new electronic systems by using other possible physical techniques to fully characterize various related compounds obtained during these studies, and also to extend this chemistry to new materials science.
elements.clean_text: Combined results obtained thus far deny a simpler description of Pt(2.25+)∞ (formally [Pt(II)3Pt(III)]∞) for the present systems, and rather support the reported mixed-valency of Pt(2.2+)∞ (formally [Pt(II)4Pt(III)]∞), which has an implication of a one-dimensional superstructure along the c axis (e.g., 5/2 c). Work in progress aims to more fully understand these new electronic systems by using other possible physical techniques to fully characterize various related compounds obtained during these studies, and also to extend this chemistry to new materials science.

metadata.title:
New Partially Oxidized 1-D Platinum Chain Complexes Consisting of
Carboxylate-Bridged cis-Diammineplatinum Dimer Cations
